abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, though only modest
            institutional development impacts were assessed. Yet, both
            performances by the Bank, and Borrower are rated
            unsatisfactory, because the shortcomings due to inadequate
            project preparation, cannot compensate the strong Bank
            implementation supervision, and, because the lack of support
            by the Government, the Government of Himachal Pradesh, and
            the Corporation's owners, led to subsequent
            decision-making failures, respectively. Lessons mostly
            concentrate on the related environmental and social impacts,
            and to those related to project preparation and
            implementation. Although run-of-the-river hydro projects,
            can have minor environmental impacts, and limited
            resettlement needs, safeguard issues need to be in place
            before implementation. In this case, during the first eight
            years, no special supervisory attention was given to
            affected people, however limited their number may have been.
            Only in the last five years were the socioeconomic surveys,
            resettlement action plan, and adoption of a corporate policy
            statement established to support issues such as
            compensation, reallocation, and income generation activities
            to mitigate adversity. Pre-conditions for project appraisal
            should include commitment by all agencies, and the
            establishment of a framework for resolution of interagency
            issues. Moreover, a good preparation should anticipate
            communication needs, including roads and telecommunications
            links, while project ownership remains essential in
            efficient decision-making, to avoid unnecessary delays. A
            financial and economic model of the project should have been
            in place at the early stages, which could have avoided those
            delays, particularly so that calculation of the "true
            cost" of implementation, could have been reached faster.

5081945.trustfund: TF035408-INDIA - RENEWABLE ENERGY, POWER PROJECTS,TF033649-INDIA - ENERGY,TF031967-INDIA - ENERGY,TF031470-INDIA - ENERGY,TF021251-PHRD-JAPANESE CTF (USD ACCOUNT)

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the project is to
            assist in meeting electricity demand in the northern region
            of India through the addition of 1500 MW of hydro capacity.
            The project will include the construction of the Nathpa
            Jhakri power station, comprising : (i) a gravity dam; (ii) a
            30 m long headrace tunnel and surge tank; (iii) penstocks, a
            power house (including 6 x 250 MW units) and a 500 m long
            tailrace tunnel; and (iv) reinforcement and expansion of the
            transmission and distribution system in the state of
            Himachal Pradesh. In addition the project will provide funds
            for consultant and training services, computer hardware, and
            software for the implementation of a program to modernize,
            streamline, and strengthen operations of the Himachal
            Pradesh State Electricity Board (HSEP), the Central
            Electricity Authority (CEA), and the Central Water Authority (CWA).
